oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is "The Cottage":, three and half miles from Jones- boro, Tennessee, where my mother Margaretta Frances Deaderick was born April 22, 1833. The Deaderick home in Jonesboro was called Poplar Hill, but my great-grandmother, Margaretta Anderson Deaderick and her son (my grandfather) David Anderson Deaderick, moved to The Cottage October 1828. My grandfather Deaderick married my grandmother, Elizabeth Jane Crozier, July 11, 1831, and brought her here as a bride. Their first child was not born here but at Fruit Hill, Knoxville, Tennessee. The next and only one of their children (my mother) was born in this little one-story brick house. They moved to Knoxville in 1834. When my grandmother Deaderick's parents, John Crozier died September 12, 1838, and his wife Hannah Barton Crozier, died October 11, 1838, then it was that Grandfather and Grandmother Deaderick moved to Fruit Hill, Knoxville. Many years ago my sister Annie and her daughter, Margaretta, some friends and I drove to Jonesboro just to find "The Cottage" and Margaretta took this picture. It was then owned by Susan Rogan, a descendant of Uncle Franklin Deaderick's family. It was rented to strangers and we saw only the wide hall running through the house, the floor of wide planks, the doors were very wide with lovely H hinges. You didn't have to call on your imagination to see that this house, though in bad repair, could have been a sweet place to live. When the house was built some time before 1828, it was considered an oddity on account of its construction being rather uncommon. Here again this home was torn down, I think to make way for the new road from Jonesboro to Johnson City. I want to make a trip to Jonesboro to see if I can find if there is any place there that is still called Poplar Hill. My grandfather Deaderick visited his brother Franklin and family who were living at "The Cottage" in 1869, and again spent Christmas week with them in 1870.
